titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: At St. John’s Church this morning where I attended with my wife, and Mary and the children— Mr Hawley read prayers for the fourth Sunday after Easter and preached from 1. Peter 1.25. [“]But the word of the Lord endureth forever. And this is the word which by the gospel is preached unto you.” There was an ingenious call for a contribution to repair the Church—a Card was placed in each pew with a pencil, with which Mr Hawley requested the person in the pew to write his name and mark the sum that he was willing to give, and to put the card into the collection bag— The money would be called for at the respective dwelling houses of the contributors— Thomas J. Frye dined with us but his mother went home— After dinner I took Louisa again to Church— Mr Hawley’s Sermon was from Luke 21.29. [“]And he spake to them a parable— Behold the fig tree and all the trees 30. When they now shoot forth, ye see and know of your own selves that summer is now nigh at hand. 31. So likewise ye, when ye see these things come to pass, know ye, that the kingdom of God is nigh at hand.” A brief and seasonable discourse; for the Peach and cherry trees are just now in full blossom; about three weeks later than the usual Season— Mrs. W. S Smith was at Church and afterwards came over to see her Sister— Richard Derby and his wife Coll. Bomford’s daughter were at Church this morning— Here from Boston, on a visit to her relations— I received this morning three remonstrances, from Plymouth, East Abington and Scituate against an Article in the Constitution of the State of Arkansas, prohibiting the Legislature from passing Laws relating to the abolition of Slavery— That from Plymouth signed by 100 females— Its appearance was somewhat suspicious, and I enclosed it to S. Sampson, the Collector of the Port, with some enquiries— I wrote also—to R. Walsh, and read a Sermon of Mr Lunt upon Spiritual Philosophy, preached at the installation of George Whitney as colleague with Dr. Thomas Gray.

Dr Huntt was here this morning and dressed again my leg, which is very slow to heal— They have news at last from the Army— General Scott has reached Tampa-Bay, without finding any Indians— Mr Frye was also here, to enquire if we had any Letters from Lieutt. T. B. Adams; but we had none— Neither have they any from Robert Buchanan— Dr Kraitsir one of the Agents for the exiled Poles, came to recommend to me a Bill before the house concerning the Lands in the State of Illinois, which have been given or sold to them, and to ask my subscription for a concert to be given here for their benefit— After dinner an old man in the 80th. year of his age, named Benjamin King, upwards of thirty years a workman in the Navy-Yard came to ask my aid to obtain an increase of his pay— He formerly received 3 1/2 dollars a day, and they have now razeed him to 1 dollar which is perhaps more than his present service is worth.— But he says he cannot live upon it, and he thinks it strange that I cannot obtain for him two dollars a day, upon which he could make out to subsist— I referred him to the President, or the Secretary of the Navy, or if they could not relieve him, to a petition to Congress. But he said he did not know who would write a petition for him; and I did not know what the petition could allege— Edward Barnard a Clerk in the General Land Office came to ask me to pay 100 dollars rent which he owes to Johnson Hellen, and receive repayment from the wages of his Son, who is one of the boys in service at the House— I told him he might give Mr Hellen a draught upon me for the money. I called at the Bank of the Metropolis— At the Book-binder Blake’s with Vol. 49. of Niles’s Register— At Montandon’s, and took my Chronometer—at Mr Joseph M. White’s where I saw his bust and that of his wife by Greenough, and sundry other Pictures, Lithographies and other curiosities from Italy; at the Athenaeum, but found it closed, and met there J. I. M’Kay. At the Patent Office with a Letter of enquiry, from Spooner Bourne at Plymouth, which a Clerk said he would answer. My wife and Mary spent the Evening with Mrs W. S. Smith.

On reaching the House this morning I was informed that Richard I. Manning a very excellent member of the House from South Carolina, died suddenly on Sunday last at Philadelphia— There were only four members of the Committee of Manufactures who attended the meeting this morning—Adams, Denny, Lee, and Webster; absent Dickerson, Granger, Judson, Holsey and M’Comas— I read the amendments prepared to the Senate Bill N. 99— Mr Lee inclined to the opinion that it would not be expedient to make any reduction of duties at the present Session— Adjourned to meet Thursday Morning at 9. O’Clock— At the meeting of the House, immediately after the reading of the Journals, Henry L. Pinckney announced the decease of his late Colleague Richard I. Manning, upon whom with much sensibility he pronounced an obituary panegyric— A Resolution to wear crape 30 days, was immediately passed—then an order to communicate by message the Event to the Senate, and the House adjourned— Mr Hoare introduced to me Mr Abel Cushing a member of the Senate of Massachusetts, now a visitor here. I went to the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and prepared a minute of the subjects referred to the Committee, to ascertain whether the Committee wish that a report upon them should be made— Then into Burch’s office where I examined the Constitutions of Alabama, and of Missouri—and finally into the Library, where I looked for documents respecting the first enactment of the English Navigation Act— There is in the Statutes at Large, and in the Statutes of the Realm a chasm from 1640 to 1660. not a single Act of that period is in the Books— But in the Journals of the House of Commons, I find the appointment of St. John and Strickland as Ambassadors to the Netherlands— The announcement of their return from their embassy, and the introduction and progress of the Navigation act— Here I was obliged to arrest my searches and went home— Evening wasted in a teizing parody upon the first and Second Stanzas of Horace’s Ode to Aristius Fuscus— How exquisitely beautiful!

The House met at ten O’Clock— The Resolution for watering the Pennsylvania Avenue was first called up and on a question whether the yeas and nays there was found no Quorum— Then was moved a call of the House, and the yeas and nays taken upon it 79 to 37. but as several other members came in while the yeas and nays were taking the further proceedings upon the call was suspended— The Resolution for watering the avenue was resumed, and after an hour’s debate was laid on the table by yeas and nays 88 to 84— Several Bills from the Senate were twice read and referred to Committees— At Noon the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union; John Y Mason in the Chair, upon the Bill making appropriations for the support of the army for the year 1836— Cambreleng then withdrew his proposed amendment of increasing by more than a Million the appropriation for arming the fortifications, and introduce it into another Bill— Among the Appropriations was one of 725 dollars to pay taxes for 1835 assessed by the State of Pennsylvania, on the United States Arsenal on the Schuylkill river, which after some debate was struck out.— There was a long debate on a motion of Sevier of Arkansas to strike out the appropriation for Fort Gibson, and to substitute the same sum for another fort to which the troops at Fort Gibson should be removed— Sevier’s amendment was adopted—after some other amendments the Bill was reported to the House together with the amendments of the Senate to the Navy Appropriation Bill, amended— Hawes objected to the Sections proposed by the Senate for authorizing a surveying and exploring expedition to the South Sea, as amended by the Naval Committee of the House, and reported by the Committee of the whole, and moved to adjourn— This was rejected by yeas and nays; but after an hour of struggling to get the Bill through the House adjourned, without passing the Bill— On returning home I found Mrs W. S. Smith here— My wife and Mary spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s— Saw in the House Mr Norvell and Governor S. T. Mason of Michigan

Met at 9. O’Clock the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, M’Comas, Webster— Absent Lee— The Amendments that I had prepared to the Senate Bill 99. were discussed and adopted with amendments— The question was again discussed whether any provision should be proposed concerning the tinted linens, and finally decided that no alteration of the existing law. 5 to 3 Granger, Holsey Judson, M’Comas, agt. Webster—Denny and Dickerson, Adjourned to Saturday Morning 9. O’Clock— I found the House in Session, in Committee of the whole, with the Navy Appropriation Bill before them and about reporting the Bill to the House, with the Amendments of the Senate, amended by the Naval Committee— In the House— Hamer of Ohio objected to the Amendment proposed by the naval Committee, and Mercer said he could not vote for the Bill without the Amendment— Hawes made a Speech both against the amendment of the naval Committee and the amendment of the Senate— Vinton supported the Amendment reported by the Committee— Patton commenced a Speech of objection upon Constitutional grounds when the first hour expired— W. B. Sheppard chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, called for the special order of the day— The business of the District—a motion to suspend the rules and order to continue the debate on the Navy Appropriation Bill, was lost by yeas and nays 114 to 68. not two thirds— The Bill for the relief of the Cities of Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria was debated in Committee of the whole, Ward in the Chair— The Bill and its parts were obstinately contested by Hawes, Graves, Vinton Mann of New-York, Jarvis and others, and supported by W. D. Sheppard, Mercer, Washington and others— The Bill was at length reported to the House; and adjourned at 1/2 past six— Found Mrs Smith at our house—and Thomas J. Frye— We all attended L’Abbés May Ball— This is the dancing School, which our two Granddaughters attend. Miss M E Woodbury was the Queen of May.— About 11 at Night we came home— Thomas Frye came home to pass the Night at our house

Mr Dickson had asked me last Evening if I would receive him this morning, and he came— He unfolded his great plan of gathering all the Indian tribes of North-America, and making the conquest of California, and finally of Mexico— The man appears to be demented; but his discourse gave me much concern, as to the prospects of our public affairs with Mexico— He is now attempting to raise a body of 1200 men, to carry a War into Mexico against Sant Anna This conversation detained me till half past ten, when I found the house in Session, receiving the Reports of the Committees— R. M. Johnson Chairman of the Military Committee moved that an hour of next Tuesday should be specially set apart for certain Bills for Military preparations, which was agreed to— A motion from the Committee on the Public Lands to fix a day for considering the Bill for reducing and graduating the price of the Public Lands, was amended by adding Mr Clay’s Bill for distributing among the States the proceeds of the Sales of public Lands— Motion to lay the whole subject on the table made by Patton yeas 91 nays 91— The Speaker voted ay and laid all on the table— Sutherland says the vote shews how the land lies— The Bill for the relief of the three Cities of the District was then taken up, and supported in a sensible and modest speech, by W. B. Shepard and opposed in a two hours speech by B. Hardin; to whom Mercer replied with much eloquence— An Amendment was then proposed by Thompson of Ohio, and carried by yeas and nays 89 to 67.— Then another by Jarvis; carried by 101 to 63— Other amendments were proposed and rejected finally the question of the passage of the Bill to a third reading was taken and carried 109 to 71— Then after a struggle to postpone the question of the passage of the Bill, and abortive motions to adjourn was again taken by yeas and nays and it passed by 1 or 2 to 68—and the House adjourned about half past five— I took Jarvis home— Charles J Ingersoll was in the House and called me out— He has just returned from a visit to Mr Madison.

Met the Committee of Manufactures at 9. Present, Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, Lee— Absent M’Comas and Webster. The Committee voted that the Chairman should report to the House the Bill from the Senate N. 99 with the Amendments agreed upon by the Committee—and that a separate report should be made on the other subjects referred to the Committee—and that Mr Jackson should prepare a report upon the subject— Adjourned without fixing upon the next day of meeting— Found at half past ten the House engaged in Committee of the whole upon the amendments, of the Senate to the Bill of appropriations for the civil and diplomatic expenses of the Government—they were reported to the House and partly adopted; one or two disagreed to, after a nibbling debate upon an item for indexing and binding Gales and Seaton’s collection of old public documents— The house then went into Committee of the whole Elisha Whittlesey in the Chair, upon a Bill reported yesterday by Cambreleng Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, appropriating one Million of Dollars for the defence of the Western frontiers— The instructions to General Gaines and the despatches from him together with a Statement of what was said by the Secretary of State Forsyth, in a conference with the Mexican Minister Gorostiza were now communicated to the house, and gave rise to a long and very warm debate, not so much against the Bill, as upon the deficiency of the Executive communications— In this debate I spoke twice, not more than ten minutes each time— The Bill was reported to the House, with an amendment moved by M’Kay, passed to a third reading by yeas and nays 146 to 3. The opposition, about 78 in number not voting at all— The Bill was then passed without taking again the yeas and nays, and the house about half after six adjourned— The excitement of the debate and of my own Speeches short as they were, affected my lameness considerably, and gave me warning to retire from the political battle-field betimes (Turpe senex miles)

I was yet unable to walk further than St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley performed the morning and evening service for the fifth Sunday after Easter, and preached a morning Discourse from Jeremiah 16.–19. [“]O Lord, my strength and my fortress, and my refuge in the day of affliction”— Mr Hawley has very recently lost his eldest son, a youth of 15 or 16 years of age, and his Sermon was obvious written under the sorrows of this bereavement— He was more pathetic than usual; but the Psalms of the day were yet more impressive— His afternoon text was from 1. Timothy 4.9. [“]This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation”— Rather a singular text, without reference to the saying itself; which in the Epistle is a declaration of the superior profitableness of godliness, to bodily exercise— The President was at the morning service— Notice was given that the repairs of the Church would be commenced to-morrow week; and afternoon there was a prayer for a person at the point of death without hope of recovery— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas dined with us, and my wife and Mary went and passed the Evening with Mrs W. S. Smith.— I employed the leisure of the day in answering a Letter of the 11th of January from E. Price Greenleaf; and in reflections upon the debate of yesterday, and the condition of our public affairs especially of our relations with Mexico— The prospect of more comprehensive and momentous discussion, and my own condition so infirm—so helpless— So nearly hopeless— The last Night was not to me a night of repose—nor of much refreshing sleep. I shall henceforth speak in the House of Representatives, at the hazard of my life— I received Letters this morning from Robert Walsh, from the Revd. Charles W. Upham of Salem and from Francis Page of Locust Creek Virginia

I found at ten O’Clock the House in Session, and the Clerk was reading a Resolution offered by Horace Everett of Vermont, calling upon the President for copies of all Instructions to the Representatives of the United States in Mexico, since the 1st of January 1835 relative to the boundaries between the two Nations, and relative to the setting on foot Military Expeditions by Citizens of the United States against the Mexican Province of Texas—and relative to the military occupation or contemplated occupation under the authority of the President of any post or place within the Province of Texas—and all correspondence and communications which have passed at Washington or at Mexico between the two Governments respecting the same and all information in possession of the executive respecting the same—and all orders or instructions issued to the Military or other Officer of the United States, or the States relative to the defence of the Western frontier and all correspondence between them and the government respecting the same. The resolution was received and lies over one day— The Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky relating to the distribution of the proceeds of the public Lands, were taken up, and Sherrod Williams made a party Speech against Hawes— Then half an hour was wasted in useless struggles for the admission of the presentation of Petitions— L. Lincoln succeeded in getting through a joint Resolution from the Senate authorizing the Secretary of War to receive informal evidence in support of the Massachusetts claim for expenditures in the last War with Great Britain— The order of the day was called and the Navy Appropriation Bill came up—the question was on the Amendment of the Naval Committee to the Senate’s Amendment of two Sections authorising a surveying and exploring expedition to the South Seas— Patton, Hamer, John Read, Hawes, S. C. Phillips, and Dickerson, discussed this question which was carried 92 to 68—and the Bill with another was sent to the Senate—the Fortification Bill was again barely taken up M’Comas obtained the floor and the House adjourned—a Mr Kenney brought a history of manufactures, and I had an Evening visit from Mr James T. Austin of Boston.

Met at 9. O’Clock the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Judson, Lee, M’Comas, Webster—absent Holsey— I laid before the Committee the Bill prepared for incorporating the Manufacturing company at Georgetown—which after adopting a proviso reserving the right of Congress to alter, or repeal the act at their discretion, I was directed to report to the House— Denny alone voted against reporting the Bill, but proposed two proviso’s one forbidding the company to issue notes in the nature of Bank Bills—and the other requiring some provision for the education of the children employed in the factory— But they failed— In the House the Resolution offered yesterday by Horace Everett, was adopted without opposition— I read an Article published in the Globe this morning, stating that the President of the United States had declared that he had no recollection of having been consulted concerning the boundary in the Florida Treaty of 1819— I reasserted the fact in the most explicit manner— Reports of Committees were then called, and after them Bills from the Senate. A question whether the Bill for distributing the proceeds of the Public Lands, should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union, to the Committee of Ways and Means, and or to the Committee on the Public Lands—was ardently debated till one O’Clock— Then three Bills reported by the Chairman of the Military Committee, were debated till two in Committee of the whole and reported to the House. Some discussion of a bill to make a military road of 1000 miles through the territory, West of Missouri and Arkansas— Then at two O’Clock, the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Abijah Mann in the Chair upon the Army Bill; and M’Comas made a Speech of 2 hours to about 50 members—the rest being all at the races— The Committee rose, and in the House an amendment by the Senate to the exploring expedition section of the Navy Appropriation Bill was sharply debated, by Graves of Kentucky—and me— The amendment was finally agreed to by yeas and nays 80 to 65— I met Reynolds and told him the result— He said he could now die content.

I went to the House soon after 9. O’Clock—and gave the Bill to incorporate a Cotton manufacturing company at Georgetown to be copied in the Clerk’s Office— In the House, Reports from the standing Committees were called— I reported from the Committee on the Public Lan Manufactures, the Bill from the Senate N. 99. reducing the duties on certain Articles of import, with amendments—referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— The question to what Committee the Bill from the Senate for distributing among the several States the proceeds of the public Lands, should be referred was debated till one O’Clock; by Gillet, Granger and Briggs. Bynum of North-Carolina, sputtered to get the floor without success. At one the fortification Bill came up as the order of the day, in Committee of the whole on the Union, Abijah Mann in the Chair. Townes of Georgia, made a speech of two hours, presidential electioneering, formally answering the Speeches heretofore made by Bell of Tennessee, and by Robertson of Virginia upon the Navy Appropriation Bill—for it is becoming a common practice to make long Speeches upon one Bill in answer to long Speeches upon another— Townes sent to the Clerk to read, many extracts from Speeches and Letters of H. Clay, and Hugh L. White to prove their inconsistency—and he replied with some point to Bell who was not in the house (there were not more than sixty members in the house, the rest were at the races) and to Robertson who was— In defence of Jackson’s proscriptions from Office, Townes charged me with having when Secretary of State dismissed a printer of the Laws, who was in favour of General Jackson, and appointed in his place one friendly to me— I interrupted him and denied the fact—adding that the only change of Printer in Tennessee that I ever made was at the request of General Jackson, (whether he recollects it or not I could not tell) and of his colleague John H. Eaton— I further said that I had never removed any person from Office, for political opposition to me— Townes finished soon after 3. the Committee rose and the House adjourned— I went into the Library and consulted Thurloe’s State Papers. Saw Persico there— In the Evening I had a visit from James A. Shedd of Dayton, Ohio— Who spoke of Antimasonry and the Cumberland road.

Mr Patterson came to enquire what was the condition of the Bill in his favour, which he said had passed the Senate— I did not know, but told him I would not enquire— At the House there were several minor measures which consumed the first hour of the sitting— Haynes moved a suspension of the rules to take up the Resolution from the Senate for adjourning the two Houses on the 23d. of this Month but it was rejected 80 to 104— Rice Garland of Louisiana made an explanation, to contradict false reports of his Speech in the House last Saturday, on the appropriation Bill for the defence of the Western frontier. I made one also, after reporting from the Committee of Manufactures, a Bill to incorporate the Georgetown manufacturing company, which was referred to the Committee of the whole House, made the order of the day to-morrow and with the Petition to be printed— The question to which Committee the Land Bill, should be referred was then debated till one O’Clock— George Chambers made a short Speech, Sherrod Williams as usual a shallow one, and Bynum, a fire and fury one, in the midst of which the hour of one came, and the order of the day—the fortification Bill in Committee of the whole on the Union, Abijah Mann in the Chair was called—French of Kentucky commenced a heinously dull Speech and three fourths of the members went to the raceground— Part of them returned about four O’Clock; and soon afterwards the House adjourned— In the Evening I went with my wife and Mary to the Concert at Carusi’s Salloon to the Concert for the benefit of the Polish exiles.— There was one man, who performed on the Violin, one upon the Piano, one upon the Mandoline and Guittar and one Singer, all of the order of mediocrity— Yet was I well pleased— Met the Vice-President Van Buren and several members of Congress there. We came home about 11. O’Clock— Coll. Josiah Quincy was at the House this morning— Here with Mrs Quincy for a day.

On coming to the House, I found there was an Article in the Globe, editorial charge of falsehood against me, with an array of documents from the Department of State to prove that General Jackson was not at Washington on the day of the signature of the Florida Treaty—and from this Statement to infer the falsehood of my averment that General Jackson had been consulted upon the Florida Treaty, before it was signed— Immediately after the Journal of the House was read, I asked permission to make another explanation— Objection was made, and Granger moved a suspension of the rules, to enable me to make the explanation; which was carried by an almost unanimous vote; I made the explanation accordingly; upon which Adam Huntsman of Tennessee, asked permission to make a Speech— There was objection also to this, but the rule was again suspended; and he made his Speech; which was a mixture of archness, buffoonery and ignorance, with Spirit and good humour, as all his Speeches are— His great annoyance was that I had charged the President with keeping the globe to lie for him— I made no reply to Huntsman, But Bell of Tennessee came afterwards to my table, and said that what I had spoken of the Globe was not one particle too strong. I told Bell, that I had had thoughts of referring Huntsman to him as he spoke for the Tennessee delegation— He said he wished I had— That he would have sustained my statement— He had already made the same complaint in the House and intended to repeat it— Cambreleng moved to take up the fortification Bill but the House refused— Private Bills were considered— Three times successively the House went into Committee of the whole and passed upon one hundred Bills— I spoke very briefly upon two—that for John Randolph Clay, and that for Relief Harris—both of which were reported to the House, and passed to the third reading— There were less than one hundred members present—three fourths of the day— Adjourned about five O’Clock. The majority of the House, were at the race-ground— William Jagger of Long Island came and spent the whole Evening with me making enquiries about the colonial Trade—and the Revd. Mr Taylor—the Sailor’s preacher of Boston brought me a Report of the Society, and spoke of a Bill for employing boys at Sea.

I went to the House this morning with the determination to take no part in the debates of this day—feeling the necessity of entire composure, before I renew the debate upon the relations of the United States with Mexico— I shewed the two Resolutions which I propose to offer to Briggs, Reed and Abbott Lawrence of the Massachusetts delegation, and to Mr. Granger of New-York; to which neither of them objected.— A Message was received from the President, with voluminous documents in answer to the Resolution offered by H. Everett—the Message only was read, and with the documents was referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations, and ordered to be printed— S. C. Phillips read all the documents and gave me some account of them. Several attempts were made in the House to suspend the Rules, to make certain Bills the special order of the day—to have preference over all other business, but they failed— Private business was taken up—a number of Bills at the third reading were passed; one or two were rejected, and one concerning a claim of property in the Pea-patch in the river Delaware was debated nearly three hours by Dickerson of New-Jersey, Howard, Milligan of Delaware, Balie Peyton, Reynolds of Illinois, and as Milligan got the floor for a second Speech a motion to adjourn was carried— I took Jarvis home— Mr Plantou called me out from the house to shew me the model of a boat that he has invented for navigating narrow canals and shallow waters— I had a long conversation with Graham H. Chapin, and a short one with James I. M’Kay— In the Evening I examined the American Almanack for the Elements of the Eclipse to take place to-morrow Morning, and was disappointed to find that it would not be annular here, though it will be and central at Edinburgh in Scotland. I calculated this Eclipse at Cambridge in April 1787.

Morning Sky— Crystal clear. Eclipse of the Sun from 6:53 to 9:20. A.M. 7 digits 13 1/2 eclipsed— It did not affect the light of the Sun perceptibly— I attended church at the morning service, at the Presbyterian Church— There were two young men in the pulpit, one named Burrows who preached, and the other Fowler made the short prayer before the last singing— The text was Psalm 76:10. [“]Surely the wrath of man shall praise thee: the remainder of wrath shalt thou restrain.” There was nothing of the animation and fire of Mr Bishop’s composition— But there was good sense, and some learning— The manner very temperate— Mrs Frye was here after Church but would not stay to dine— After dinner, with Mary-Louisa at St John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the Sunday after Ascension day. His text was from Acts 5.40.—[“]and to him they agreed; and when they had called the apostles, and beaten them, they commanded that they should not speak in the name of Jesus, and let them go. 41. And they departed from the presence of the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer shame for his name.”— The sermon very short— Mr Hawley repeated a notice which he gave this morning, that to-morrow the repairs upon the Church would be commenced, and it would be two or three weeks before they could be completed so that the services could be resumed. He exhorted the Pew holders to liberality in their contributions. Coll. Josiah Quincy with Mrs Quincy, and his Sister Abby Quincy were here this Evening— They were to have left the City yesterday morning but Mrs Quincy was too unwell for a rail-way journey— They propose to go to-morrow. Mrs Quincy is in very bad health.— My time and attention and Sentiments are becoming absorbed in the danger of a War with Mexico.— I read a Speech of a Coll. Wharton, one of the Texian Commissioner, at a great meeting at New-York—and for the second time the address of S. F. Austin another Texian Commissioner to a very large meeting at Louisville ladies and gentlemen—

Mr Jackson, the member of the House, called upon me with his Son-in-Law and his daughter. John H Sherburne came also and told me he was about to publish a second edition of the life of Paul Jones, and he wished a certificate from me of the authenticity of his journal— I declined giving him the certificate, but said he might mention that I had read the Journal or a part of it— At the House— Petition day— But the Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, in favour of the bill for distributing the proceeds of the Public Lands were again taken up and Graves made a Speech in support of them, of about an hour— Then a motion was made and carried to postpone the subject till next Monday— Then Sutherland moved for leave to suspend the rules that he might present the memorial from Philadelphia, in favour or the Texians, and Vinton moved to amend for the reception of a similar memorial from Cincinnati— Not carried— W. B. Shepard moved to suspend the rules to take up, the Amendment of the Senate to the Amendments of the House, of the Bill to purchase the stock of the Dutch Loan from the District Cities. it was carried and after a sharp debate the Amendment of the Senate was adopted—and thus the bill was passed— A Bill from the Senate for carrying into execution the last Treaty with Mexico for running the boundary line, struck out a hot debate by Wise, Balie Peyton and John Calhoon against John Y. Mason, Bouldin, Vanderpoel, and Cushing, till five O’Clock when the Committee rose and the House adjourned— There was glorious news from Texas, transmitted in Hand Bills—that Santa Anna had been defeated and taken by Houston, and shot with all his Officers— Mrs Frye dined with us— My wife was very unwell, with a sore throat and hoarse voice.

The change from Winter to Summer has taken place in 24 hours— Sunday and yesterday morning we had fires in our dining room, and wanted them in our chambers— This day we have high Summer heat— Mary and her children rode with me to the Capitol— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal I asked the consent of the House to offer two Resolutions calling upon the President for copies of any overture made by his authority since the 3d. of March 1829. to the Government of Mexico for the acquisition of any territory, of that republic, by the United States and any question of boundary between the two Countries; and for copies and Translations of any Law, Ordinance or Decree of the Mexican Government, abolishing Slavery within the Territories of that Republic— Objection was made and after several attempts to postpone my question I insisted on its being taken and the permission was refused by yeas and nays 74 to 85— Reports were then received from standing Committees and about 20 minutes before one the Rules were suspended till then to receive Petitions and Resolutions for Post-Offices and Post-roads— The Bill as amended by the Senate appointing the Attorney-General sole commissioner to adjudicate the claims under a Convention with Spain, was taken up and John Y. Mason chairman moved to disagree to the Senate’s Amendment, and made a short Speech to explain the provisions of the two Bills— I did the same to sustain him the Amendment was disagreed to without opposition. At one the House went into Committee of the whole upon the fortification Bill, and Abraham P. Maury made a White electioneering Speech of 2 hours and a half—when he finished Forrester of Tennessee asked the Committee, he not having his Notes for his Speech with him to rise, and they did rise, and after various struggles to take up other business, and a call of the House commenced and suspended, adjourned about 4. In the evening I had visits from the Revd. Mr Lothrop and W. S. Cruft who brought me a Letter from his father—

Immediately after the reading of the Journal, H. L. Pinckney, presented the Report of the select Committee to whom all the abolition Petitions were referred and said that the report had the unanimous assent of the Committee— He moved that 5000 copies of the report should be printed for the use of the House— It was immediately attacked with extreme violence and a fiery debate arose which continued until one O’clock, and then by a suspension of the rule for another half-hour. Motion was made to print ten thousand and twenty-thousand copies, and Waddy Thompson said that he would commit it to the flames or to the hang-man— Ben Hardin who was a member of the Committee declared his dissent to the main Sentiment of the report, and protested against it— At half past one the order of the day was called, and in Committee of the whole, Mann of New-York in the Chair, Forrester of Tennessee, made his White electioneering Speech of about one hour—then the Bill for the Defence of the Western frontier, amended by the Senate so as to turn a militia levy into a ten thousand men addition to the army— M’Kay objected to this amendment, and I made a warm Speech against it, and was answered with much virulence by Lawler of Alabama, and by Glascock of Georgia— The previous question was called by Mann of New-York who refused to withdraw the motion, to allow me to reply to Lawler and Glascock. The previous question was carried; but the Senate’s amendment was rejected 102 to 104. Then after an abortive attempt to adjourn, Cambreleng presented a Bill appropriation of half a Million of dollars for the suppression of the hostilities of the Creek Indians, which passed through all its stages with some skirmishing debates for information of the causes of the War— The House adjourned after 6— My wife was very ill, and bled by doctor Huntt.

Attended a meeting of the members of the Massachusetts delegation in the chamber of the Committee of Commerce which had been requested by me to consider of the expediency of doing some thing, to give effect to the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, respecting the North-eastern boundary of the United States— Present Mr Webster of the Senate—and Adams, Borden, Calhoun, Cushing, Grennell, Hoare, Jackson, Lawrence, Lincoln, Phillips and Reed; absent Davis of the Senate and Briggs of the House, who was engaged upon another Committee— After some conversation it was agreed that Mr Webster should offer to the Senate a Resolution calling upon the President for communication either confidential or otherwise, of the present condition of the controversy with Great Britain respecting our North Eastern Boundary, with all the correspondence relating thereto, and particularly the preliminary conditions exacted by the British Government, for their consent to the resumption of the Negotiation— Mr Webster prepared such a Resolution, which was agreed to and he said he would shew it to the Senators from Maine before offering it, and give notice to our delegation when the answer to the Call shall be received— In the House the Resolution of Caleb Cushing for printing 15000 extra copies of the documents concerning the Bill for defence of the Southwestern frontier, and the correspondence with the Mexican Government Elisha Whittlesey moved to reduce the number to 5000 but at my request withdrew his motion—the Resolution passed without opposition— Then the question upon the printing of 5000 extra copies of H. L. Pinckney’s Slavery report was discussed, and Bynum made one of his fiery Speeches—which lasted with an interruption from Pinckney till Noon, when the special order of the day, the Bill for re-organizing the Post-Office Department, was debated in Committee of the whole on the Union, Sutherland in the Chair till past six in the Evening when the House adjourned after voting by two thirds to take up the same bill to-morrow, at and after eleven O’Clock. Jarvis went home with me— My brother’s widow Mrs Ann Adams, with her daughter Mrs Angier, and her son Joseph H. arrived this Evening from Quincy.

Joseph H. Adams rode with me as far as Gadsby’s— At the House, the first thing brought on after the reading of the Journal, was the report of the conferees, on the disagreement between the two Houses, on the Amendment of the Senate to the Bill from the House for the defence of the Southwestern frontier— The conferees of the House were Dixon H. Lewis, Ripley, Carr, Coles andLewis reported that the conferees of the two Houses had not been able to agree, and he was instructed by the Committee of the House to move that the House insist upon their disagreement to the Amendment of the Senate; but he made a Speech on the opposite side of the question, and said he hoped that some Gentleman would move that the House should recede. Glascock accordingly made the motion, and a hot though short debate followed—the hour of eleven came and the order of the day was called—but the rules were suspended by yeas and nays 126 to 37. to continue the discussion it was continued and the Previous Question moved seconded and carried 106 to 76.— The motion to recede was rejected by 103 to 67. Then the vote to insist was carried without division. Then Lewis moved to ask a second conference of the Senate to which I and others objected on the ground that if a conference should be held, it was for the Senate to ask it.— The Order of the day was called and the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Sutherland in the Chair on the Post-Office Bills. Shields of Tennessee made a Speech of an hour in support of his incendiary section amendments; and was briefly answered by Hiland Hall—the amendments were rejected—as were many others of trivial import—the Bill was finally laid aside and the annual Post-route Bill taken up— The Senate asked a second conference on the Western frontier defence Bill which was agreed to—

I called at General Macomb’s Office this morning, with two Letters from my Son Charles and from Mrs Ann Adams to Lieutt. Thomas B. Adams, which I requested the General to forward, which he promised— He returned home the Evening before last from his military expedition to Florida—not over glorious— Mrs Adams and Mrs Angier with Mary Louisa, went with me to the Capitol; going to judge Cranch’s— At the House, the motion of Robertson to recommit H. L. Pinckney’s incendiary petition report with instructions to report a Resolution declaring that Congress have not the power to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, was first taken up, and Robertson made a Speech to the Walls of about three quarters of an hour—and when the time for the order of the day came, White of Florida prevailed upon the House to take up a Bill for paying certain unpaid Volunteers in the Florida Indian War— The Bill itself was reported a month since; and there was no opposition to the Bill—but Martin of Alabama offered an amendment, for paying the reasonable expenses of eleven companies of mounted men, when he had only called out five companies, and only five were accepted—this after a debate of two hours he withdrew— Owens of Georgia then offered another amendment providing that the sums required for the execution of the Act, should be appropriated from any monies not otherwise appropriated—this also he withdrew— Then White of Florida moved an additional Section to which Glascock moved an amendment which were debated till near six O’Clock, when the Bill was passed to the third reading and passed without division— Then Lewis from the Committee of Conference on the disagreeing votes of the two Houses, on the Volunteer and Militia Bill— The Senate have yielded the point; and the report of the Committee of Conference was unanimously accepted by the House— The House adjourned before six O’Clock— Jarvis came home with me— I was called out of the house by a Revd. Mr Osgood, who had a subscription paper for building a protestant Church in Montreal, Canada, which I declined to sign— Also by Mr Whitcomb late a Clerk in the Customs-house Boston.

I went this morning with Mrs. Ann Adams Mrs Angier and Joseph H. Adams, to the Unitarian Church, and heard Mr S. K. Lothrop of Boston, from 1. Corinthians 7:23. “Be not ye the Servants of men.” an admirable Treatise upon the abuse and the use of example— We had gone under the expectation of hearing Mr Taylor—the Seaman’s preacher, but notice was given that he would preach this Evening— I met Mr W. W. Seaton who told me that the news of the Texian victory of the Texians over the Mexicans was all confirmed; and that Santa Anna was actually a prisoner; but not shot— He said all the details of the battle had been received— After Church Mr Hassler called upon me and left papers with me respecting the survey of the Coast, and the preparation of weights and measures— Mr and Mrs Frye, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, and Thomas J. Frye, dined with us. In the Evening I went with Mrs A. Adams, Mrs Angier and W. S. Smith again to the Unitarian Church, and heard Mr Taylor, the Seaman’s preacher from Romans 12.1. “I beseech you therefore brethren by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies, a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service 2. And be not conformed to this world; but be ye transformed, by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove, what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect will of God.” Mr Taylor preaches without notes— He is animated, lively, fluent, deeply interested in his subject, and powerfully impressive in his manner, which is earnestly hortatory— He commented upon the beauty of the text, connected it with the preceding chapter, and pointed his whole argument to the conclusion that the Service of God is a reasonable service. In his prayer, he alluded specially though not by name to Mr Clay, whose son John has been ten days at the point of death with a brain fever. He is a Student at Princeton College, now here in vacation— I met Mrs Katherine Brown, at Church— It was past ten O’Clock when we came home.

Called at the Department of State, and left there a Petition of Edmund Richards of Hingham, for a Patent for a Drawing Cutter, with duplicate drawings of the Article and of a receipt for 30 dollars paid into the Treasury by the Petitioner— The Secretary of State was not at the Office—detained at home by a bilious Colic— The Chief Clerk Asbury Dickins took the papers— At the House, the Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentuckey recommending the Bill distributing the proceeds of the Sales of the public Lands, were first in order, and Caleb Cushing made a splendid rhetorical Oration, in support of the Resolutions; and the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, to the same effect. He spoke about an hour and a half— Haynes of Georgia, followed, and read a Speech of about half an hour.— Then Hannegan moved to lay the Resolutions, and the motion of Chilton Allan to refer them to a Committee with Instructions to report a Bill distributing the proceeds of the Land sales to the States in proportion to their federal population, upon the table, and declared he wished to have it considered a test question— There was a call of the House, which was suspended when 192 members had answered to their names— The motion to lay on the table was carried by yeas and nays 110 to 89. and thus settled the question of the public Lands, and of the surplus funds in the Treasury, and of the monies of the deposit Banks at this Session— The fortification Bill then came as the order of the day, in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Mann of New-York in the Chair— Forrester of Tennessee finished his White opposition Speech, which he began last week— Mercer moved an Amendment, authorizing the purchase or establishment of a Cannon foundery, and made a short Speech; which was succeeded by an infuriated declamation of Pickens— Then after a refusal of the Committee to rise, a speech by Underwood, interrupted by repeated risings of the Committee for want of a quorum—one call of the house refused, and an agreement to fix tomorrow 11. O’Clock to resume the Bill, the House adjourned at half past 8. in the Evening. Visit afterwards from John Connell.

I received a Letter this morning from my Son Charles, with extracts from my Diary of February 1819. Mrs A. Adams, Mrs Angier and Joseph went with me to the Capitol, and I introduced them to the Library— At the House, judge Jeremiah Smith asked me specially to make a Speech, which I promised him to do if the House would permit me— Immediately after the reading of the journal, I asked the unanimous consent of the House to offer the two Resolutions of call upon the President for information concerning our Affairs with Mexico, which I moved last week, and I asked the permission of the House to assign my reasons for offering the Resolutions—objection was made, and Chambers of Kentucky moved to suspend the Rules, to enable me to assign my reasons, which was rejected— I then moved the suspension of the Rules to enable me to offer the Resolutions—and asked for the yeas and nays— Huntsman said he would vote for my introducing the first Resolution, for he knew that the President was perfectly willing to communicate the information— I then modified my motion for leave to offer the first Resolution— Waddy Thompson said he would vote for my Resolution with an amendment asking the opinion of the President as to the acknowledgment of the Independence of Texas— The vote for suspending the rule was 82 to 68. a majority but not two thirds— The printing of Pinckney’s Slavery report, and Robertson’s motion to recommit the report with Instructions followed, and Robertson continued his argument till eleven O’Clock, when the fortification Bill was resumed in the Committee of the whole on the Union— Abijah Mann in the Chair— Underwood finished his Speech, then Chilton Allan, offered an Amendment to the Amendment to the Amendment presented by Cambreleng— I objected to this as not in order, and so it was declared by the Chairman. Mercer then withdrew his amendment, and Allan offered his amendment which was for a general reduction of the Salaries of Executive Officers, and members of Congress— Then a squabble between Jenifer and Thomas, and battling till One O’Clock in the morning, when the Speaker adjourned the House till ten O’Clock Wednesday Morning.

Mrs A. Adams, and Mary rode with me to the Capitol— At the House, the motion of Robertson, to recommit Pinckney’s Slavery Report, with Instructions to report a Resolution, declaring that Congress has no Constitutional Authority to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, as an amendment to the motion for printing an extra number of the report was first considered— Robertson finished his Speech which was vehement, and he read the Letter from Mr Van Buren on the subject of the Power of Congress to abolish Slavery in the District, and he charged him with evading the question. I asked that so much of the Letter as he had referred to should be read and it was—immediately after the conclusion of Robertson’s speech I addressed the Speaker but he gave the floor to Owens of Georgia, one of the signing members of the Committee, who moved the previous question, and refused to withdraw the it— It was seconded and carried by yeas and nays 110 to 89— I asked what the main question would be—the Speaker decided that it would be the adoption of the Resolutions of the Committee, which have not been in the slightest degree discussed— I appealed from the decision which the house confirmed.— The question on the first Resolution was taken 168 to 9.— Glascock asked to be excused from voting— I required that the reasons for excusing him should be entered on the Journal— The Speaker was doubtful—the hour of one came and the order of the day was called— A joint Resolution from the Senate authorising the President to cause rations to fur furnished to suffering fugitives from Indian hostilities in Alabama and Georgia Committee of the whole on the Union, and a debate of five hours, in which I made a Speech of about an hour; in which I opened the whole subject of the Mexican, Indian Negro and English war— Answered by Lawler, Haynes, Waddy Thompson and Wise— The Resolution was carried through all its Stages, and passed and the House adjourned between 7 and 8 O’Clock, and I came home much exhausted—and soon sought my bed—

I had a very indifferent Night, and little sleep— At the House the first subject was the question upon Glascock’s, assigning the reasons for his asking to be excused from voting on the Slavery Report Resolutions— The Speaker announced that he had recurred to the only precedent on the Journals of the House, which was in my own case; and that the House then determined to proceed in the call of yeas and nays, and announce the decision without waiting first to decide any question on the refusal of the member to vote— But that such question would remain to be afterwards decided by the House— I rose and began to prove that the case was totally different from that of 1832 which could not therefore apply as a precedent; but I was called with great vociferation to order and not permitted to proceed. The Speaker went on and announced the result of the vote on the 1st. Resolution— On the call of yeas and nays upon the second Resolution, I asked to be excused from voting, and the call was continued passing me by.— Others declined voting and they were also passed by. On my name’s being called on the third resolution I answered I hold the Resolution to be a direct violation of the Constitution of the United States—of the Rules of this House and of the rights of my Constituents— They passed on— Granger asked to be excused from voting on the second Resolution, because the Resolution is different from that which the Committee was instructed to report— He was passed over and not allowed to offer his reasons. A Scene of great disorder ensued— Glascock claimed the floor to assign his reasons— The Speaker gave him the floor, and then took it away from him by arbitrary, absurd and inconsistent decisions, all of which were sustained by the House by large majorities by yeas and nays; as were the three Resolutions reported by the Committee— The Bill for the re-organization of the Post-Office was then debated till about 5. O’Clock when it was made the special order of the day, with preference over all other business to-morrow, and the House adjourned— I walked home, the first time for nearly two months— Mr Gales gave me a note requesting me to write out my Speech of yesterday to be reported in the National Intelligencer.

At the House this morning, upon the reading the Journal, I saw that the proceedings of yesterday were not truly stated, and moved amendments, only the first of which was adopted— The Journal stated the decision against Glascock’s tendered reasons for asking to be excused from voting’s being received before the decision of the Houses’s Resolution, being announced, without stating that Glascock had tendered his reasons, so that the Journal gave the Speaker’s decision, without shewing what the subject was upon which the decision was made. After long discussion all my other amendments were rejected some with and some without taking the yeas and nays, and the decisions of the Speaker were all sustained— Granger, Glascock, Robertson and Wise all moved amendments which were also rejected— Dixon H. Lewis however obtained an entry upon the Journal of his reasons for asking to be excused— This debate consumed four hours, before the Journal was read through— Then the order of the day, special, was called—the Bill for the reorganization of the Post-Office— The Amendments, reported from the Committee of the whole were coldly, mumbled over, till Vanderpoel moved an amendment to the new tariff of postages proposed by the Committee, and objected to any increase of the existing rates of postage— This opened a wide debate, to a multitude of speakers— Cambreleng moved an amendment to the new tariff of postage proposed by the Committee, and withdrew it— Mr Lawrence renewed it, and after sharp debate it was carried by yeas and nays 88 to 85— Mann of the Committee then moved that the amended Section itself should be rejected. The debate now assured a party complexion, and became heated, till past six when the Bill was made the special order of the day with the preference on Monday and subsequent days till finished, and the House adjourned— Mrs A. Adams, Mrs Angier and Mary had been in the gallery and I went home with them— I have an inflammation in the left eye—

Mrs. Angier and Joseph H. Adams rode with me as far as Mr Elliot’s. I found the House in Session, and Mr Stockton at Prayer— After the reading of the Journal, Hamer of Ohio, asked permission to present a memorial and Resolutions from a meeting at Toledo, which he said he did not wish to be read, but merely to be laid upon the Table— I asked that they should be read; and it was a bitter complaint that the memorialists were oppressed by the conflicting authorities of two State Governments at once— I asked if the member from Ohio would state whether the Memorial and Resolutions were from Citizens of Ohio, or of Michigan— He said that the Memorialists and he considered them as Citizens of Ohio; but that I and the People of Michigan considered them as Citizens of Michigan— The Speaker then said that he had received a Memorial and the proceedings of a Meeting in the County of Monroe upon the subject of the boundary of Ohio and Michigan which he had been requested to present to the House— I asked that the Resolutions and Memorial should be read, which the Speaker with evident signs of reluctance ordered— They were ardent remonstrances against the Bill for the admission of Michigan now before the House— There was a motion immediately made to lay them on the table. I moved that they should together with the Bills from the Senate fixing the Northern boundary of Ohio, and for admitting the State of Michigan into the Union, be referred to a select Committee—the Speaker referred to the rule that Petitions shall not be debated on the day when they are presented—and said these motions must lie over one day.— The House soon got to the order of the day for private business— The Bill for the relief of the legal representatives of Dr. Gale brought up the question of the Pea patch— Joseph R Ingersoll, John J. Milligan and P. Dickerson made long and warm speeches, upon the claim of the States of Pennsylvania New Jersey and Delaware to the property; but they were all refuted by D. J. Pearce in behalf of the private claimants— The Previous Question was then called—no Quorum— Call of the House ordered by yeas and nays, and then an immediate adjournment of the House; and I walked home.

lg.l: Just in the last distressing hour
The mount of danger is the place
Where we shall see surprising grace

div.p: I went this morning with Mrs Ann Adams and Mary to the Capitol, and heard Mr Stockton the Chaplain of the House of Representatives preach from John 3.16. “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him shall not perish, but have everlasting life.” Mr Stockton is a methodist, and this is a text upon which men of that persuasion may expatiate by the hour or by the day. He spoke without notes, and as if he sincerely believed not only his text, but all his own inferences from it— Mr Stockton passes for an eloquent preacher, but he had not this day the faculty of gathering a crowded congregation— I never saw the hall so thin at the performance of public worship on the Sabbath— I think there were less than one hundred persons present— After Church we called at Gadsby’s to visit Mr and Mrs Abbott Lawrence, but they were not at their lodgings— After dinner I attended at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Farrar a young Clergyman from Albany— His Sermon was from 2. Timothy 2.12. “If we suffer, we shall also reign with him.” There was nothing remarkable in the discourse; but the lines as the top of this page are the closing verse of one of the hymns which he gave out to be sung— There is scarcely a Sunday passes over my head, but in attendance upon divine service, I hear something of which a pointed application to my own situation and circumstances occurs to my thoughts— It is often consolation; support—encouragement.— Sometimes warning and admonition. Sometimes keen and trying remembrance of deep distress. The lines above cited are of the cheering kind— I was occupied all the leisure of the day and evening in writing out for publication my Speech made last Wednesday in the House of Representatives, one of the most hazardous that I ever made, and the reception of which even by the People of my own district and State is altogether uncertain.

Mrs. Ann Adams and her Son Joseph rode with me to the Capitol, at the House, it was petition day, but H. Johnson, asked permission to present several petitions to which I objected and gave notice that I should object to every petition, until the House should carry into effect by receiving petitions by the Call of States— There was then a motion to suspend the Rules, to consider the Resolution from the Senate for adjourning Congress, on the 23d. of this month— I enquired whether the House could consider a Resolution to adjourn upon a day that is already past. Heister offered to amend his motion so as to make it an original proposition to consider the time of adjournment But the House refused to suspend the appeal— Another motion to suspend the Rules was made to consider a motion reported by the Committee of Ways and Means to fix a day for debating the Bill regulating the deposit Banks—upon the Call of yeas and nays on this question John M. Patton asked to be excused from voting, and his name was passed over, and after the roll was called through Patton asked the Speaker, if he adhered to his former decision of announcing the result of the vote before taking the sense of the House whether he should be excused or not. The Speaker said he should upon which Patton appealed from the decision, and a debate of six hours ensued— About 3 O’Clock a motion to lay on the table the appeal was carried by a vote of 96 to 91. but on that question Jenifer asked to be excused, and the Speaker having passed him over the debate was renewed— I was the last Speaker against the decision which was again affirmed 108 to 61. and before the House adjourned. After waiting three quarters of an hour for my Carriage, I rode home— We have had four days of chilling Easterly wind, and this day heavy rains— We passed the Evening by the side of a comfortable fire— Second full moon this Month.

On my way to the Capitol I overtook Mr Philemon Dickerson a member of the House from New-Jersey, who rode with me— I found the House in Session, debating as usual sundry motions to suspend the Rules to enable members to move to fix certain days for the consideration of certain measures in preference to all others— They were all rejected or laid on the table— Sundry reports from Committees were received till eleven O’Clock, when the order of the day was taken up which was the Bill for re-organizing the Post-Office— The reconsideration of the amendment carried last Friday at the motion of Abbott Lawrence fixing a general reduced tariff of postages was first debated upwards of three hours, when the house refused to reconsider, the vote of Friday— Then the question came on agreeing to the amendment reported by the Committee of the whole as amended by the motion of Mr Lawrence which was lost by yeas and nays 75 to 90.— So that the existing rates of Postage are to be continued.— My motion to reconsider an Amendment to the 5th. Section by which the Treasurer of the United States was required to give receipts for all monies deposited in Bank, without saying in what Bank, as of monies received— After a short debate, the Amendment was reconsidered and rejected, and the Section restored as originally reported in the Bill.
